title: AB 2330
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 10083.2 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to read: 10083.2. The commissioner must provide online information about the status of all licenses issued by the department, including suspensions, revocations, and accusations. Personal information like home phone numbers and social security numbers will not be included. The commissioner must disclose a licensee's address of record, allowing for a post office box or alternate address instead of a home address. A licensee may also be required to provide a physical business or residence address for internal administrative use only, not for public disclosure. Section 10083.2 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define "Internet" and specify the expiration date of the section as January 1, 2018, unless extended by a later statute. The commissioner must provide online information about the status of all licenses issued by the department, including suspensions, revocations, and accusations. Personal information such as home telephone number, date of birth, and social security number should not be included. The commissioner may disclose a licensee's address of record, allowing for a post office box or alternate address instead of a home address. A licensee may also be required to provide a physical business or residence address for internal administrative use only, not for public disclosure. Upon petition and payment of a fee, the commissioner may remove discipline postings from the bureau's website after 10 years if evidence of rehabilitation is provided, considering other violations that pose a risk to the public. The bureau may establish fees and requirements for licensees to petition for disciplinary record removal, with evidence of rehabilitation needed. The process will start on January 1, 2018, and a list of altered records will be shared with other licensing bodies. The commissioner will provide online information on license status in accordance with specific acts. This section will be repealed on January 1, 2018, unless extended by a later statute. The commissioner will provide online information on suspensions, revocations, and accusations related to licenses issued by the department. The commissioner will disclose a licensee's address of record, allowing for a post office box or alternate address. A licensee may also be required to provide a physical business or residence address for internal use only, not for public disclosure. The public information disclosed will include whether a licensee is an associate licensee and identify responsible brokers. The definition of "Internet" is clarified. This section will be effective from January 1, 2018. Section 10083.2 is added to the Business and Professions Code. The commissioner will provide online information on license status, including suspensions, revocations, and accusations filed. This is in accordance with the California Public Records Act and the Information Practices Act of 1977. The commissioner will disclose a licensee's address of record, allowing for a post office box or alternate address. A licensee may also be required to provide a physical business or residence address for internal use only, not for public disclosure. The public information disclosed will include whether a licensee is an associate licensee and identify responsible brokers if the associate licensee is a broker. The definition of "Internet" is as stated in the relevant section. The commissioner may remove a discipline posting from the bureau's website if a licensee provides evidence of rehabilitation after 10 years, showing no credible risk to the public. Other violations that pose a risk will be considered in the evaluation of the petition. The bureau may establish fees and requirements for licensee petitions, including evidence of rehabilitation. Disciplinary actions will be considered "posted" as of the date they are taken. A list of licensees with altered disciplinary records will be maintained and shared with other licensing bodies. This section will be effective on January 1, 2018. Effective January 1, 2018, amendments to Section 10161.8 of the Business and Professions Code require real estate brokers to notify the commissioner in writing when a salesman is hired or terminated. Licensees must update their license with new business addresses and employing brokers accordingly. Section 10161.8 of the Business and Professions Code requires real estate brokers to notify the commissioner in writing when a salesperson is hired or terminated. Licensees must update their license with new business addresses accordingly. This section will be repealed on January 1, 2018, unless extended by a later statute. Whenever a real estate salesperson changes brokers, they must update their license with the new broker's information. This section will be effective from January 1, 2018. No reimbursement is required by this act according to the California Constitution as it pertains to new crimes, infractions, penalties, or changes in crime definitions.
